newsitem.title: USA: US 1996 rail intermodal, ton-miles at record -- AAR.
newsitem.headline: US 1996 rail intermodal, ton-miles at record -- AAR.

text.p: U.S. 1996 rail freight traffic as measured in ton-miles and intermodal surpassed records set in previous years, the Association of American Railroads said Friday.
The AAR said total volume in 1996 was estimated at 1,320.2 billion ton-miles, up 1.9 percent from the previous record of 1,295.3 billion in 1995. A ton-mile equals one ton of freight hauled one mile.

AAR said 1996 intermodal volume totaled 8.12 million trailers and containers, up 1.7 percent from the previous record of 7.98 million set in 1994 and a 2.3 percent increase over 1995's 7.94 million. Intermodal volume does not include carloads.
But total carloads last year reached 17.7 million, down 0.5 percent from 17.8 million in 1995.
"In the abstract, 1996 traffic levels appear disappointing, mainly because of the 0.5 percent decline in carloadings," Harvey Levine, AAR chief economist, said.

"But when viewed against record traffic levels in 1995, poor weather conditions in the early months of the year and a disastrous export grain market, the 1.9 percent increase in ton-miles reduces the dismay," Levine said.

In the week ended December 28, carloads totaled 242,710, down 6.8 percent from 260,513 in the same 1995 week. Intermodal traffic stood at 105,672 trailers and containers in the week, a six percent decrease from 112,433 a year ago.
Ton-miles in the December 28 week were 18 billion, off 5.3 percent from 19 billion in the year-ago week.
